data.text:
#KaranKunjur #NeelKunjur #K2Space #MegaClassSatelliteBus "Los Angeles-based startup K2 Space raised $50 million in new funding as the company works to build monster satellites to match the massive rockets that are coming to market. Nearly two years since founding, K2 co-founders and brothers CEO Karan Kunjur and Chief Technology Officer Neel Kunjur expect to launch their first satellite on a demonstration mission later this year. The company’s latest fundraiser was led by tech investor Brad Gerstner’s Altimeter Capital and joined by Alpine Space Ventures, adding to the $8.5 million in seed funding it raised from investors including First Round Capital and Republic Capital. K2 declined to specify its valuation after the most recent round. “This round is effectively built for the demand that we’re seeing for launching constellations of the Mega class satellites,” Karan Kunjur told CNBC. K2′s Mega class satellite bus — the physical structure of a spacecraft that provides power, movement and more — is sized to fit in “heavy” and “super heavy” rockets. Some of those rockets are currently in operation, such as SpaceX’s Falcon 9 and Falcon Heavy rockets or United Launch Alliance’s Vulcan, and some are expected to come to market in the coming years, including SpaceX’s Starship, Blue Origin’s New Glenn and more. The company advertises its Mega satellite for $15 million each and says they’re capable of supporting up to one ton of payload mass each. At that size, K2 would be able to fit 10 Mega satellites in a Falcon 9 rocket. “We have a pretty modular design, where the customers can dial in just how much payload mass they want, how many satellites they want to launch, and how much propellant they want to carry,” Neel Kunjur said, adding that “the intent is basically to give a customer a menu of options where they can dial it into their given mission needs.” K2′s upcoming demonstration mission aims to show numerous undisclosed customers that its Mega design works. In addition to discussions with various commercial “large satellite operators,” Karan Kunjur noted that K2 has won about $6.5 million in Department of Defense contracts over the past eight months. “There are different parts of the DOD that are incredibly excited about the capability that we’re able to offer at the constellation level,” Karan Kunjur said. K2 currently has a 15,000 square foot facility in Torrance, California, and 28 employees, many of whom, like Neel Kunjur, boast years of prior experience at SpaceX. The Kunjurs expect to use the fresh funds to add a 150,000 square foot facility later this year and grow the company to more than 50 employees as it prepares to begin producing satellites. “The goal is really to get into [the larger facility] by the end of the year and be able to start switching gears into mass production … to really make sure we’re hitting the scale that our customers are asking for,” Karan Kunjur said."

Exciting Developments in the Space Launch Services Market 🚀🌌 The Space Launch Services market is experiencing a transformative shift, and it's a thrilling time to be a part of this industry! 🌠 Sample report @ http://surl.li/mvflp With the increasing demand for satellite deployment, space exploration, and the growing number of commercial ventures in space, the Space Launch Services sector is poised for incredible growth. 🛰️💼 Here are a few key trends shaping the market: 🌟 Reusable Rockets: Companies like SpaceX have demonstrated the game-changing potential of reusable rockets, reducing launch costs and making space more accessible. 🌟 Smaller Satellites: Miniaturization of satellites and the rise of small satellite constellations are driving a need for more flexible and cost-effective launch solutions. 🌟 International Collaboration: The industry is seeing greater cooperation between countries and private entities, fostering innovation and expanding global reach. 🌟 New Entrants: Numerous startups are entering the market, injecting fresh ideas and competition into the sector. 🌟 Space Tourism: With companies like Blue Origin and Virgin Galactic, space tourism is on the horizon, offering new opportunities for the launch services market. This dynamic landscape presents significant opportunities for professionals, businesses, and investors alike. 📈 K2 Space Corporation Raises $50 Million For ‘Monster Satellites’... K2 Space, a Los Angeles-based startup, secures $50 million in its latest funding round. Spearheaded by Altimeter and Alpine Space Ventures, this financial boost marks a significant leap towards manufacturing the next generation of large-scale satellites. Key Highlights: 🔹K2 Space is set to revolutionize the space industry with its Mega-class satellites, designed to complement the massive rockets of today and tomorrow. 🔹With an ambitious design spanning 27 meters across its solar panels, these satellites are built for efficiency and scalability. 🔹Founded by the visionary Kunjur brothers, K2 Space eyes its first satellite launch on a demo mission later this year. 🔹Previously backed by $8.5M in seed funding, the company is now a key player in the push for larger payloads and more efficient launches. 🔹Compatible with heavy-lift rockets like SpaceX’s Falcon 9 and the forthcoming Starship, the Mega satellites promise cost-effective space transport solutions. 🗣️ CEO Karan Kunjur shares, "This round is effectively built for the demand that we’re seeing for launching constellations of the Mega class satellites." At $15M per satellite, K2 offers unparalleled modularity and customization for their clients, including the Department of Defense. With plans to expand their facility and workforce, K2 Space is gearing up for mass production and a future filled with possibilities.
